results.title: Are Hurricane Shutters Mandatory in Florida? - Storm Smart
results.description: Hurricane shutters are not mandatory for all homes in Florida, but state building codes require certain homes in high-risk areas to have impact-resistant windows, doors, or approved storm protection.

results.description: Do you need a permit to install hurricane shutters in Florida? Yes, in most cases, you need a permit to install hurricane shutters in Florida, as the state has specific building codes to ensure safety during hurricanes.

results.title: Can Florida HOAs Stop You From Installing Hurricane Shutters or Generators? - Storm Smart
results.description: Under Florida HB 293 (2024), HOAs must allow code-compliant hurricane shutters, impact windows, generators, and reinforced roofs. Learn exactly what your HOA can, and can’t, restrict.

results.title: “Hurricane Window Protection Policies & Local Regulations” – CAI Community Voice | Becker & Poliakoff
results.description: In the wake of Tropical Storm/Category 1 Hurricane Elsa, and with September being National Preparedness Month, hurricane preparations are top of mind for many owners and associations, as are considerations for how long hurricane shutters, plywood, or other protective window coverings should remain in place following an active threat of a storm. Section 718.113(5) of the Florida Condominium Act requires each board of administration of a residential condominium to adopt hurricane shutter specifications for each building within each condominium operated by the association.

results.title: Hurricane shutter - Wikipedia
results.description: The Miami-Dade County norms, often considered the most stringent requirements for hurricane shutters, rely on self-developed testing methods TAS201, 202 and 203. Passing the tests prescribed by the TAS norms is required only for shutters approved for use in the Florida HVHZ (High Velocity Hurricane Zone).

results.title: Category 5 Hurricane Shutters - What Are Hurricane Rated Shutters?
results.description: If you live in a High Velocity Hurricane Zone (HVHZ), such as Miami-Dade, Broward Counties, Monroe County or Coastal Palm Beach County, the building code requires HVHZ (high velocity) approved shutters. These may also be referred to as Category 5 hurricane shutters, high velocity hurricane shutters, or category 5 hurricane shutters. They will be marked with “Meet Florida Building Code for HVHZ” or “Approved for use within HVHZ”, or similar.

results.title: “Hurricane Shutter Policies Raise Questions” – News-Press | Becker & Poliakoff
results.description: For example, I remember reading a condominium arbitration decision many years ago that found a board rule to be unreasonable, stating that if the board wanted to require shutters to be left open, the association would need to be responsible to deploy them in the event of an approaching storm. Arbitration decisions are not “the law” but rather an opinion of one attorney, in one dispute, and are not entitled to judicial deference under the Florida Constitution.

results.description: The FBC is a set of regulations dictating minimum construction standards, including hurricane protection. Shutters meeting FBC standards are suitable for most areas in Florida.
